div.p: For the last while I have seen a hand full of stories talking about algorithmic writing, for journalism, for books, etc. Basically software that'll create a magazine article or a book all by itself without a human's help. And the quality seems pretty good.

Reading some of the press surrounding this algorithmic writing, it makes it sound like it is something new, but it really isn't. Algorithmic writing has been used for quite a while in "gaming" search engines.
But on the topic of algorithmic writing, I think it would be interesting and even useful to create an algorithmic writing system that can create moral-laden writing for different moral frameworks.
It would be even more useful if combined with technology that can detect a person's moral framework.
With respect to creating such a system, if people have a presence on (online) social networks, there's a lot of analysis you could do.
For a simple example, look for communities (in the graph theory sense of the word). Although most community detection algorithms are non-convergent, so look for 'community cores' instead.
One could even use the text (or video or audio, etc) associated with the 'community core' to feed into the algorithmic writing system.
Although that is something I consider "low hanging fruit" from an algorithmic point of view.

There's other "low hanging fruit", from an algorithmic point of view, too. And with some offline and online analysis work, via a machine learning system and help of humans, one could improve said algorithmic writing system a lot. (At least in part, taking an interative, trial-and-error approach to developing the system could be useful.)
And just to say it explicitly, there's different sources of data that could be used. (Online) social networks is just one example. I'm not trying to be exhaustive.
